instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWGD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PWGD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Arrived with the classic exploded capacitor causing short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Replaced cap which restored <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> but still no power.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0V

<SIGNAL>PCH_SUSACK_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> 0.52V

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWGD</SIGNAL> 0V

What next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: yes drops from 3.3v to 0.358v when  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>   is triggered

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Then check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
Also try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
yes there is a pulse at  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> 

no start at SMC bypass mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Then check for pulse at all big coils.
Also check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> (for pulse).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
If you tap the the bottom side of the board in CPU section at times the fan will spin and boot properly according to bench power supply  but only for a few seconds to a couple minutes then turns off again.

Does this sound like a internal problem with the new behavior?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Test the board alone on the desk; do not connect LIO flex.
Also try with original Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: I already have the board alone on the desk now with no LIO flex

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Check for corrosion at <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
And do the mentioned tests...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
During testing noticed L7560 voltage was fluctuating. A couple times the fan even spun during the test. Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> but no change. Should <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> be replaced?

Yes there is a pulse at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Check for pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
Inspect all SPI Bus Termination resistors and their traces.
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulses too?
Any pulse detected at CPU coils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
yes pins 7&3 pulse. While testing pin 3 the fan started spinning and stayed spinning until unplugged. After unplugged and test again no fan spin.

termination resistors are traces are fine

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulses

no pulse at CPU coils

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Pin 3/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> cannot pulse, if no pulse at VCORE too; which is not easy to detect.

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <CAPACITOR>C7540</CAPACITOR> voltages are steady high when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
Check for voltage pulse, or short, at pages 57 & 58.
